segments.text: institutional idea, man, to realize that there were two constraints on what was going on in Navy research.
If you had a private industry, that company had to make profit.
If you had the Navy, you had to have something to go on a ship to fight a war with.
And
This did put constraint on people's thinking.
The worst case that I had was in a certain laboratory where when I'd go down to talk about the research program, they would put the comptroller in his head at the table.
And just the fact of the man's presence there with the dollar sign swinging from his neck almost made the fellows in the laboratory very cautious and even cut down on what I thought I wanted to see.

The biggest single thing that I know of, two biggest single things that I know of to handle this problem was Gordon Lill's beginning the informal coordinating committee on oceanography and Finn and Jennings and Fetter and Lill and Maxwell and others initiating the Tannock plans.
At least
This answers the criticism of the Navy that we were just asking for carte blanche.
At least we indicated where we hoped to go, and they could buy it or not buy it.
Unfortunately, they didn't buy it.
While working in Scripps, while you were involved in doing research,

Well, they let me work on bathy thermographs a little bit, and things of that kind, and little projects of measuring temperature in the sea, but really the GI Bill of Rights carried the tuition, and I was so unfitted to be a scientist that it took all my time really to keep up at all.
Dr. on the final verbal exam.
He gave us a lecture on the Gulf Stream the day before.
And the next day, my examination in French was the exact text that he had coded from.
The text of the Gulf Stream.
That's where his genius lay, that he knew I'd never get through my language requirement otherwise.
Now, while you're though at Scripps, now Ravel comes back, doesn't he?
Ravel came back as director of MPL, it seems to me, and a co-director with Carl Eckert at one time.
I remember just about the time we left Scripps, he came back, yes.
I don't know what, I'm confused as to what he was, where he was, 46 to 48, I don't know.
Okay.
Do you seem to remember, was his return back to Scripps welcomed with enthusiasm or not welcomed with enthusiasm?
Oh, I think so.
I think so, and I, with all due respect to... Carl Eckhart?
No, the director, present director of Scripps.
Nirenberg?
Nirenberg.
who has made, I think, a very, very wonderful record.
It was something of a surprise, though, that when the big university campus was established, to many of us, that Roger didn't get it.
Throughout the University of California at San Diego?
Now, here again, it could be...
It's a difference in aim and the necessities of the case.
The University of California had, what, 20,000 students they had to take care of, whereas Roger wanted to make Scripps an ivory tower of excellence.
And as a matter of fact, the compromise worked out pretty well, I think.
But you can see what the very strong feelings must have been at the time, and who was right, I don't know.
Well...
The whole point of this being is that in this period of time, several oceanographic institutions are rising into periods of excellence.
As a matter of fact, Challengers to Woodhull, turning out competent PhDs.
What was your impression of the sudden implosion and explosion of oceanography between about 45, really 48 and 56, first of all?
I thought it was terribly exciting sitting over at the Bureau of Ships.
I was called in on...
as a representative to watch it.
I remember the International Geophysical Year was such a wonderful move forward, and yet you'll have to look at that we had some very practical men at the head of it.
There were four institutions who got the
majority of the funding of that year.
On the east coast it was Columbus, Island, and Woods Hole.
On the west coast it was Revelle and Scripps.
And I won't say satellites, but Miami on one side, Texas A&M on the other.
That's the way it went.
And as soon as that had been decided, then they got down to basic research.
As soon as they split the funds up.
I didn't say that.
The
In the early days, it was a very lucky thing that people who had the broad vision and also the ability to write these papers on which large amounts of money were transferred were still around.
Plus Wakelin over in R&D there.
It was just a bunch of wonderful coincidences, plus a devoted effort on the part of everybody involved.
These people were...
were dead serious.
They had a dream.
And, uh, Morris Ewing had his, Ravel had his, Spitter had his, and the, Columbus had his.
The, the great leaders of that old Harrison Brown's Oceanographic, uh, National Oceanographic Committee, marvelous.
the job that they did.
Did you seem to think that Sputnik in 57 put much input into the development of oceanography?
Yes, it did from the popular mind.
Very, very decidedly so, as Rechnitz and the others will tell you, and I've talked it over with him.
I had him down here to talk about it.
The Trieste deep dive to the Marianas Trench was the only big outstanding scientific event that we could show in the earth sciences field that in magnitude came anywhere close to Sputnik.
And it was our only answer to it for some time then.
I think the Trieste Diver was completely justified on that one basis.
That has to be the only basis.
What about Moho?
Moho got mixed up in the politics.
Perhaps it's well that it didn't go through with all the expense because of the plate theory.
Now it seems to say that they wouldn't have found too much anyhow.
I don't know.
But I would have liked to have seen it done.
There's a cute story in connection with that.
Gordon Little had to answer a letter to ONR from an old Navy chief.
Please don't let them bore that hole in the ocean because you know what's going to happen.
All gravity is going to leak out of it and we'll all be out and out of space.
How do you explain the politics that were obviously involved in Moho vis-a-vis what seems to be a lack of politics in the Trieste mission?
Am I misconstruing those two missions?
No, not at all.
The Trieste was a single agency thing.
Bob Dietz went over there and came back with a wonderful report.
When I bought the view, I remember sitting around at the conference table, about nine people, and me, I'm scared of the dark and all that sort of stuff.
And I said, well, who in the world would go down in the dark thing anyhow?
And to my amazement, nine people's hands, who I highly respected as scientists as well as administrators, went up.
And with that encouragement, O&R had it.
Now, O&R, after that big dive, though, it was a white elephant to them.
Yeah.

And we took it over, and it was a white elephant to us to a certain extent, except that what we learned from it about deep submergence and the hull stuff, which is a whole area in itself that I think more than justified doing it.
But again, it was two agencies, not more than two agencies talking, where my captain could say, yes, we'll put $800,000 on the line.
And in Mohul, there's more than two agencies, certainly.
Well, AMSOC was a social drinking society and a good time society taken over by Bascom and his group as the name of their committee.
And you had people from the scientific as well as the industrial.
You had to bring in the industrial people.
The Navy couldn't do it all by themselves, even on the survey part of it.
And so your politics got into it, and then, of course, it got into Brown and Root, and there you are.
Would you like to make any comments about Brown and Root?
No, I won't make any comments, because I didn't know anything about it, except what I read in the papers.
I just thought that it ballooned quite a lot.
Now, after 57, when the first expansion of...
Well, between 57 and 63, you create oceanography departments all across the country, largely with funds aided by ONR.
ONR directed and affected the development of those old departments of oceanography.
What about the Bureau of Ships' role in that?
Well, I think that's when my programs began to become solely dependent upon ONR in support of
good research like Waldo Lyon and Gene Lafon and others in the Navy laboratories.

There was a function of support of research wherever it was that ONR had to fulfill and of course you had to take care of its own parent organization's outfits and with few exceptions we had good scientists on those programs.
The use

Another thing that was occurring at that time was that the old know-how was going out of the Bureau of Ships, and actually out of the Navy, being contracted to industrial firms, and this called for more and more reorganization and more diversification.
It had to be, for instance, people in the landlocked states of Idaho and places like that began to get into oceanography.
study programs, well, that's all right.
Some of the best geologists came out of Arizona.
Now, what's your reaction to your reorganization now as your bureau changes, really, in this period?
What really changed and what ended my program as I knew it, and it was time for me to retire when it did,
was when the source of funds at ONR were changed.
There is a category called 6.1, which is the research end of the whole research and development testing material train.
And as long as I had the money from ONR, I could have this 20% and 30% freedom of basic research in my laboratory programs.
But after that went out,
And I think it was in order to support the MISAR that year.
And I've gotten over all bitterness about the decision.
This left only the next category, which administrators could not apply to research.
They had to apply to development.
And this meant that a great many of the people I had ceased to be funded or were turned on to projects, which were, what is Mr.
Mansfield's relevance.
Funding based upon relevance.
And I think that perhaps this division of authority, certainly they have carried it out to the Hydrographic Office even right now.
That's my next question.
It seems to me that after the Mansfield Amendment, as it's called, there seemed to be a retiring in the upper echelons of all the agencies involved in oceanography.
is that because of age factors or because of the change in the direction of the bureaucratic institutions?
Well, I think it was a lot of things.
I think the main, perhaps to me, the main thing was the change of administration just as the Stratton Report came out.
I think if the Stratton Report had come out at the beginning of, say,
Jack Kennedy's administration, you would have seen a completely different picture.
Okay.
Did you find the Nixon administration less receptive to research and development than the Kennedy administration?
I wasn't then under Nixon for very long.
Did you notice a... Do you understand any political climate before the Mansfield Amendment that seems to indicate that direction towards applied research on it?
In other words, did the Mansfield Amendment take you by surprise?
Well, I'm a person who has to get his news filtered down because I don't like to be shocked every morning by the reversals of decisions.
So I was so far out of the politics of the thing, and really my opinion would be absolutely worthless on that.
I do think that this...

proliferation that you've spoken of had already gone on and the types of research for which well you can always nitpick and I think the climate changed because I don't in my opinion I don't believe the administration under President Johnson understood oceanography to the same extent
that the seagoing, yachting-type people of Kennedy did.
And for what it's worth, it's my opinion, there's a change of administration, and then the, well, you had the Vietnam War on top of your work.
The money was, the armed services were needing every nickel to keep going, and there were some, some things had to be
and I think I have no objection to what Mansfield said at that time.
I do hope that it will not be always so literally applied.
While you were at the Bureau of Ships, did you seem to, did there seem to be an increase in international oceanography, if I coin a word for you, international cooperation that you were aware of?
I was aware of it simply because of the people that were involved.
Gene Lafon, who was my man at NUC,
I was over as a secretary of the Intergovernmental Oceanographic Committee.
Warren Worcester, who was my classmate at Scripps, was over there for a long while.
And such international meetings as, well, the big one, of course, was the 1959 International Congress in New York.
And I didn't get in on all the others, but I got in on a few of them.
And yes, I would say among them,
Well, even to some extent with the Russians, I thought there was a great increase of information.
Did this come as a surprise to you as a man largely always attached to naval functionaries?
Not really, because as far as I can see, the pattern is that when they know more than we do, we don't hear from them.
When we know more than they do, they're always there.
So I'm rather cynical on that question.
Many accomplished, you know, there are no shows in certain fields.
Finally, tell me what you think were the great instrumentational breakthroughs which seemed to shape oceanography, or change the nature of oceanography for you, beside the BT.
Precision depth recorder.
Precision depth recorder.
That is what you think...
They started Woods Hole and perfected it much more, the oceanographic tower.
This is inshore stuff.
You have to give airborne heat surveys to their proper place.
The oceanographic ship as an entity and as a tool, not just here and there, but as a necessary tool for each institution.
The satellite navigation and the underwater sound positioning.
And you have to go back, this is a system, but it was the development of, we paid for the first ones.
the underwater beepers and bottom location, and above all, the unclassified little three-point station in the Pacific of Ewing's called the SOFAR system.
Now, all those things you've listed have been primarily...
measuring devices and devices attached to what I would call exploration of the seas.
Do you see that the kind of work continuing in the future of oceanography, or do you think those devices were so effective that that sort of oceanography is ending?
Well, I have a friend up in Cambridge who's working on an airborne altimeter using a laser beam.
And they aren't satisfied until they get that kind of precision.
So you think the precision measurements then will continue?
The big problem in the whole thing is the condensation of data.
You've got data running out of your ears now, some of it biased and some of it...

I would like to see, at this time, when there is a little bit of a doldrum in research and people looking at the way they should go, a review of the Stratton Report and also a down to earth, maybe by the National Science Foundation or National Academy, some crowd like that, is to say, now, where do we stop taking data?
and spend a couple of years and the money consolidating it until we have weaned out of it all we can get before we go into a new instrumentation program.

At the same time, there has to be an ongoing project to apply to the oceans all of the marvelous developments in electronics that are going on and in the nuclear field that are going on so fast that the average oceanographer doesn't know what tools are available again.
I don't know how to put that together.
I should think it would be a function of NOAA.
So you don't... Make sure I'm inferring this correctly, but you feel...
I do not think that we should spend a lot of money on ships today surveying, continually getting additional data, until we have cooked what we have and gotten an essence out of it.
Good, that's exactly what I want to know.
What about the computer?
You can't, it's got to be there.
There's certain problems that you can't take the wave problem.
Now, there's where your ivory tower comes in.
I think Walter Monk's group on waves, I wish he'd stay with the waves instead of going out and earth wobbling and all that, but he's too big a man to tie down.
But I'd like to see that thing worked out theoretically to the limit before we go out and take any more wave measurements.
Now you could sell a great deal more of this if you would get a good tsunami prediction system that isn't dependent upon whether or not the lighthouse keeper gets drunk that night.
I'd like to see a better, a better, a great deal, I'm delighted to see all this work on earthquake prediction.
Because the public needs this.
You can go along just so long before the democracy demands its pound of flesh.
Now, only on this line, I have one more question.
The use of glamour fields has sort of come and gone in the last several years in oceanography, you know, nuclear physics, physical oceanography.
Some, of course, never came in, like marine biology and oceanography.
What do you think will be the glamour field in oceanography in the future?
Sometime we're going to have to pay the bill of all this advertising about what the oceans can do for humanity.
And how are we going to do that with 77 nations saying, get off my back?
Somehow you've got to bring back the dream of the oceans as something useful to the man in the street.
How are we doing, Paul?
Good.
Now, that's the last series of questions I want to ask you.
I have four specific questions I want you to offer your opinion on.
You don't have to pretend to be an expert on this.
Aquaculture, are you optimistic?
Yes, I am.
I've been reading the Marine Letter of the Tri-State, Virginia, North and South Carolina.
I believe that out of that is going to come something that will be commercial success.
And certainly it'll be the only way of saving what we have got.
Okay.
In terms of aquaculture, do you think it'll produce anything but specialty foods like shellfish or crustaceans?
Do you think it'll?
No, I think it's going to have to be for the next 20 years.
We're lucky if we get one line of mass production out of it.
Okay.
Do you see any hope for such things as plankton and kelp, for example, in mariculture?
I was thinking mainly of my particular love of the marshes.
No, I don't know anything about the deep sea.
Okay.
Secondly, mining the sea for minerals other than manganese and oil, I suppose.
Are you optimistic about any of that in terms of being productive?
Not except in special cases of sands and different types of... certain types of...
chalks and things of that kind, where it is economically useful in the area where they do it.
So for example, phosphates off North Carolina, you'd be optimistic about that, but not if it can bring the cost down where it's competitive, yes.
Thirdly, the sea and pollution.
this is a discussion now on most people, involving both nuclear waste and the alleged dying sea and so forth.
Do you have any reaction to that?
Yeah.
It scared me at first, but I think I got over-scared.
The same way that people got over-scared about automobile exhausts.
I think it was Columbus, isn't it, once said that the human being is
over 10 million years have been adapting to change after change after change, ice age and everything else conditions.
I'm not going to be too frightened of having to adapt to others.
I do think this, this is one area in which I think emphasis should be given.
Just how close are we to a critical condition in the ocean?
Is it all fear of people who love the ocean and
Or is it a physical fact?
It's like the ozone layer.
Let's get the fact on the thing.

Well, do you think that publicists in opposition to pollution, people who are not really scientists, for example, like Jacques Cousteau, do you think they are a positive good or moderately positive good, or do they hurt the cause of acquiring the facts?
Well, as Rosamund said, never mind what they say about me.
Every time they publish my name, it helps.
Yeah.
Well, those are not against us as far as I'm focused on.
I think his lectures and his movies have done more to bring people back to a knowledge of what's really in the sea.
I think his educational programs are fine.
Of course, he's a master showman.
Why shouldn't they be?
I'm for him.
You have no other.
You have NATO, for instance, in the other area is pretty well damned by the man who has to buy an exhaust control.
Who else is speaking for this on an international worldwide basis any better?
And that leads to my last question in an international worldwide way.
What is your opinion on the rising political problems in oceanography?
200-mile limits, international conferences that are occurring now.
Do you think that threatens the academic discipline?
Yes, I think it threatens the untrammeled collection of information.
In other words,
In the old days, Ewing could send a vessel off the coast to any coast he wanted to and take his seismic reading.
Now he's got to go through a lot of red tape.
It's going to be more difficult.
If it's handled correctly, well, if it can be handled where the national business...
I'm torn.
I'm torn between the one world of scientific control and my complete fear of dictatorship.
I think perhaps...

Hayek, whatever his name is, has it better, that the untrammeled minds of free men working together, even from a selfish basis, can do more and will be better for humanity than any controlled oligarchy dictatorship on the thing.
The Law of the Sea Conference is a perfect mirror of the old international situation, I think.
At the present time,
I'm a nationalist.
I don't believe that we should necessarily subsidize the man who's going to go out and make a profit mining the ocean.
We should know what his interests are, though, and protect them to the extent that we can, and perhaps even to our advantage.
But I would like to see absolutely free research if the information is given to the other countries.
without the necessity of having to go through all kind of customs of having people on board and that sort of business.
Okay, now, would you list in the major items that you think of importance very quickly before?
The first was the writing of the oceans by...
